blog.name: thisiscomics
blog.title: A Panel A Day (more or less)
blog.description: I probably read too many comics. Here are some highlights. If you like, go give money to the creators.

summary: It’s strange how the depiction of spider-sense has become so familiar that this really jumped out at me. Even in the recent...
body:
It’s strange how the depiction of spider-sense has become so familiar that this really jumped out at me. Even in the recent Marvel’s Spider-Man PS4 game, the wavy lines indicating it’s time to press the evade button are instantly recognisable as spider-sense.

Cabal’s version has those lines, but they are much more stylised here, and part of a wider effect- Peter seems to have a halo, and so there’s an impression that spider-sense is more than just a tingly little squiggle emanating from the scalp. It almost seems like a physical experience, his entire head affected by this warning of danger- it almost makes me think of a migraine, pressing all round the skull.

On reflection, this seems a more plausible depiction- if it is some sort of spider-derived survival mechanism, why wouldn’t it be intensely physical? If your body wants you to react and get the hell out of the way NOW, it isn’t going to gently nudge you like a comically polite guardian angel: “sorry, I don’t want to bother you, it’s just that, well, there seems to be a bullet heading your way and, if it isn’t too inconvenient, I mean, if you want to, then perhaps you should maybe think about moving? Oh, sorry, too late.” A more visceral signal seems much more sensible if it wants to keep the organism alive. I imagine the ‘classic’ depiction is unlikely to be replaced, but it’s interesting to see a variation on that which evokes a sense of being a well reasoned change, rather than just an arbitrary stylistic one.

From Friendly Neighborhood Spider-Man 1, by Tom Taylor, Juann Cabal, Nolan Woodard & Travis Lanham

reblog.comment:

On reflection, this seems a more plausible depiction- if it is some sort of spider-derived survival mechanism, why wouldn’t it be intensely physical? If your body wants you to react and get the hell out of the way NOW, it isn’t going to gently nudge you like a comically polite guardian angel: “sorry, I don’t want to bother you, it’s just that, well, there seems to be a bullet heading your way and, if it isn’t too inconvenient, I mean, if you want to, then perhaps you should maybe think about moving? Oh, sorry, too late.” A more visceral signal seems much more sensible if it wants to keep the organism alive. From Friendly Neighborhood Spider-Man 1, by Tom Taylor, Juann Cabal, Nolan Woodard & Travis Lanham

Cabal’s version has those lines, but they are much more stylised here, and part of a wider effect- Peter seems to have a halo, and so there’s an impression that spider-sense is more than just a tingly little squiggle emanating from the scalp. On reflection, this seems a more plausible depiction- if it is some sort of spider-derived survival mechanism, why wouldn’t it be intensely physical? If your body wants you to react and get the hell out of the way NOW, it isn’t going to gently nudge you like a comically polite guardian angel: “sorry, I don’t want to bother you, it’s just that, well, there seems to be a bullet heading your way and, if it isn’t too inconvenient, I mean, if you want to, then perhaps you should maybe think about moving? Oh, sorry, too late.” A more visceral signal seems much more sensible if it wants to keep the organism alive. I imagine the ‘classic’ depiction is unlikely to be replaced, but it’s interesting to see a variation on that which evokes a sense of being a well reasoned change, rather than just an arbitrary stylistic one.

trail.content:
It’s strange how the depiction of spider-sense has become so familiar that this really jumped out at me. Even in the recent Marvel’s Spider-Man PS4 game, the wavy lines indicating it’s time to press the evade button are instantly recognisable as spider-sense.

Cabal’s version has those lines, but they are much more stylised here, and part of a wider effect- Peter seems to have a halo, and so there’s an impression that spider-sense is more than just a tingly little squiggle emanating from the scalp. It almost seems like a physical experience, his entire head affected by this warning of danger- it almost makes me think of a migraine, pressing all round the skull.

On reflection, this seems a more plausible depiction- if it is some sort of spider-derived survival mechanism, why wouldn’t it be intensely physical? If your body wants you to react and get the hell out of the way NOW, it isn’t going to gently nudge you like a comically polite guardian angel: “sorry, I don’t want to bother you, it’s just that, well, there seems to be a bullet heading your way and, if it isn’t too inconvenient, I mean, if you want to, then perhaps you should maybe think about moving? Oh, sorry, too late.” A more visceral signal seems much more sensible if it wants to keep the organism alive. summary: You expect me to believe that Spidey "just happens" to be "in the neighborhood" to meet and talk with Domino who lives in San...
body:
You expect me to believe that Spidey “just happens” to be “in the neighborhood” to meet and talk with Domino who lives in San Franciso who also, by the way, is having a birthday party downstairs where Deadpool is currently having fun with other mercs and mutants IN SAN FRANCISCO?

I think we all know that Spidey and Pooly are actually on a romantic getaway. Duh.

reblog.comment:
You expect me to believe that Spidey “just happens” to be “in the neighborhood” to meet and talk with Domino who lives in San Franciso who also, by the way, is having a birthday party downstairs where Deadpool is currently having fun with other mercs and mutants IN SAN FRANCISCO?

I think we all know that Spidey and Pooly are actually on a romantic getaway. Duh.

blog.name: jaggedheartstrings
blog.title: I Love You 3000
blog.description: plus a lot of fics |×|×|×| AO3: JaggedHearts

tags: too much fluff makes me wanna throw up but too much angst makes me sad
summary: Fluff & Angst
body:
Fluff & Angst

I love to read fluff and angst, but then when a story has so much fluff it make should wanna throw up, I need some drama too!

I read this one awesome winteriron fic called Winter’s End, which was about 455k words and most of it fluff. Got a little suffocating for a while, but the angst was really good.

Fluff is nice and all, but drama is such a relief every now and then.

Thoughts? Love’d to hear them.

reblog.comment:

summary: The first super hero comics “Spider Man” was a mugger in a furry suit with a bag of goo--Whiz Comics #89, September 1947;...
caption: The first super hero comics “Spider Man” was a mugger in a furry suit with a bag of goo–Whiz Comics #89, September 1947; Captain Marvel finishes him and his pet tarantula (;_;) in one panel at the end of the story “The Webs of Crime.” Otto Binder script, C. C. Beck pencils, Pete Costanza inks.
